” Death to Tito the pig,” they scrawled on buildings along the
Corse; ”Oo home. Winterton;” rtDown with the English.” And they also
wrote: ”Death to the U. 3. A.* Hardly a building escaped. Again
and again one saw a youngster scratch, with chalk* ”3cusa, Poroo,
se tl chiaiaa Tito” — excuse it, pig, if someone calls you Tito.”
Often they would add ***** caricatures of Tito swinging on gallows.
One easily concluded that Marshal Tito and General Winterton would
not get very many votes in Rome. But the Americans weren*t getting
many at the moment, either.
On the crowd went to the Piazza Venezia, where Mussolini used to
harangue students, along with others, from hie balcony# And there
these students were harangued by a couple of the political heirs of
II Dues.
One shouldnH overstate the case. The demonstration had its
lighter aspects. Obviously, some of the kids were just celebrating
the delicious prospect of no school on a lovely autumn day.
At one point an automobile carrying the sultry Italian motion
picture actress, Sllvana Pampanini, got involved with the crowd* And
some Italian youths forgot for the moment about Trieste to whistle and
crowd around the car and ask Signorlna Pampanini for her autograph.
And I saw one wall where some teen-ager had scrawled ”d«ath to Tito,”
but had added, just below it, a chalked heart and the legend, ”Blanca
is my love!” Some of the students were laughing and joking as they
raced along toward the Piazza Venezia.
Yet, there was fanaticism on many of those young faces; faces
of boys and girls who would have been only two or three years old
when Mussolini took Italy into World War II.
